data.title: BRZU: Positioned For A Dollar-Driven Brazil Upswing
data.description:
Holding a bullish position on the Direxion Daily MSCI Brazil Bull 2X Shares ETF (BRZU) is like taking a bazooka shot in a highly USD-sensitive macro scenario: the return potential is explosive, but the risk of volatility and decay can quickly erode capital if timing is not precise.

I believe that recent movements in global markets outline an apparent situation where we are in the early innings of a high-beta emerging markets—particularly Brazil—momentum breakout driven by carry, dollar weakness, and capital rotation. And under this context, using leverage appears to be tactically sound.

To be clear, BRZU seeks to deliver 300% of the daily return of the MSCI Brazil 25/50 index — not over a year, not over a cycle, but in a single trading day. This index represents the main Brazilian large and mid-caps, which are highly concentrated (~42%) in four companies: Nu Holdings Ltd. (NU), Vale S.A. (VALE), Itaú Unibanco Holding S.A. (ITUB), and Petróleo Brasileiro S.A. - Petrobras (PBR) (PBR.A).

BRZU manages to deliver 3x not simply by buying three times as many shares, but by using swaps, futures, derivatives, and some cash and short-term securities as collateral. There is also daily rebalancing, where every day, at the close, the ETF rebalances its exposure to maintain 3x for the following day. In a strong trend, this works very well, but of course, in sideways markets, there is volatility decay where even when the index is practically at zero, this effect destroys performance in erratic markets. And all this is done for a rather steep fee of 1.22%.

That being said, BRZU is clearly designed to be a tactical, short- to medium-term ETF — particularly useful for betting on a specific macro regime. If the current macro backdrop is indeed shifting, this may be one of those moments where leverage makes sense. In that context, I view BRZU as a Buy.

Let’s break down the macro drivers behind that view.

Macro Conditions Supporting Brazilian Assets

Brazil today has an interest rate of 15% (Selic) — recently maintained at January 28 — and inflation (IPCA) over the last twelve months of 4.44%. This implies a real interest rate of ~10.56%.

At the same time, in the U.S., the Fed funds target range is at the upper limit of 3.75% and the CPI of 2.4% over the last twelve trailing months — implying a real interest rate of only ~1.35%. This gives a real rate spread between Brazil and the U.S. of ~9.21 p.p.

In practical terms, this is a direct link to a theme of carry trade and support for the BRL as long as the “risk” regime helps. To put it even more succinctly, a global investor can capture funds in USD at ~3.5%-4%, convert to BRL, and invest 15% in a Brazilian government bond (NTN-B, "Notas do Tesouro Nacional" indexed to inflation) or other fixed income instruments, and hedge the FX partially, or not. This sequence of flows generates demand for BRL, which naturally triggers an appreciation of the BRL vs. the USD.

Since FX is largely a function of portfolio flows, if there is foreign demand for Brazilian bonds (which will need to be bought in BRL), this creates structural pressure for appreciation and a reduction in the risk premium. And this compresses the equity risk premium, leading to multiple expansion in the Ibovespa — the Brazilian stock market index.

The DXY links to this story as the USD is extremely sensitive to real interest rate differentials and global liquidity. If there is a dovish scenario from the Fed where real interest rates fall, liquidity improves, risk decreases, and the USD tends to weaken, the DXY falls because the carry advantage of holding USD decreases.

The graph below, showing foreign inflows into B3 (the Brazilian stock exchange) well above average, is very much in line with the recent acceleration in Brazilian equities and above the moving average, which leads me to believe that foreign inflows are coming in at a rate above the recent normal.

Volatility Regime and Leverage Considerations

Usually, the best time to use leverage is when volatility isn't exploding.

The most direct way to quantify this is based on the implied volatility of the Brazilian equity market itself, in this case by looking at the S&P/B3 Ibovespa VIX (the 30-day implied volatility of the Ibovespa). In the most recent print, the index was at ~21.7-22.4. And this index has varied between 11.6 and 29.1 in the last 52 weeks. The implication is moderate volatility, not panic.

In the “nerve” of the carry trade, FX, the reading also seems well behaved, with USD/BRL conditional volatility currently running in the high-single-digit range (~8% annualized), well below prior stress episodes.

And according to Direxion data, the BRZU beta regime is already responding as it should, rising 11% in one month and 46.7% in three months. This helps sustain the breakout momentum already underway, and in trending regimes the compounding effect usually works in the ETF's favor — unlike in a sideways market.

That being said, the Achilles heel of Brazil's macro thesis is still the fiscal one. To be clear, Brazil hasn't turned into Switzerland, but what really matters is that the risk is compressing. Brazil's 5-year CDS is at ~127.72, down ~10% in six months.

This is happening at the same time as there is a primary deficit of 0.47% of GDP in twelve months, and the debt to GDP ratio is at 78.7% — on an upward trajectory, which is the most worrying part. So, if one can question whether the fiscal risks could reprice, it certainly could, but the market today seems to be accepting Brazil risk at less of a premium, largely because the global backdrop helps.

Primary Risk Factors

At first glance, investors may be more hesitant about the risks associated with the composition of the MSCI Brazil 25/50 more because of the concentration in commodities, as in the case of the large positions in Vale and Petrobras, which, in theory, are impacted by more complex macro issues derived from the correlation with the iron ore and oil markets.

The interesting thing is that both Vale and Petrobras have risen more strongly, especially in the last couple of months, not necessarily tracking the underlying commodity price action over the same period, which also leads me to believe that there is a strong sensitivity to FX as a primary driver.

The risks associated with leverage, especially in an asset group that usually carries a high volatility given the country risk, are naturally around the fact that losses can compound quickly and may significantly exceed those of a non-leveraged ETF of Brazilian equities, such as the iShares MSCI Brazil ETF (EWZ), for example. For this reason, I subscribe to the idea that the BRZU should be used tactically, requiring almost daily monitoring and occupying no more than 2-5% of the portfolio allocation.

One way of structuring risk could be to use a scaling strategy, where you start with a small base position and add to it if the DXY remains weak, the flow accelerates, and commodities confirm the momentum. Or trim if vol starts to rise, flow slows, and DXY stabilizes.

The Bottom Line

I believe this is a good time to be a BRZU bull as there is still plenty of opportunity to make good money amid what looks to me like a very clear and strong ongoing rotation to EM, and with Brazil at the epicenter of that movement due to carry, FX, and risk premium compression.

But going long a leveraged ETF that seeks to track equities from an emerging country involves constant risk management, which is why I would advise moderately measuring positions according to one's level of risk tolerance and reducing exposure if conditions deteriorate.

data.title: Rolls-Royce: Buy As The Dividend And Buyback Engine Starts Spinning
data.description:
Rolls-Royce (RYCEF, RYCEY) posted its full-year earnings, which included an upgrade to the company’s growth expectations. Since my last report, the stock price has increased 4.6%, once again outperforming the S&P 500. In this report, I analyze the full-year earnings and outlook for Rolls-Royce, which I believe provides sufficient reason to remain bullish on the stock, as the company is now pivoting to a shareholder-return-focused setup.

Rolls-Royce Growth Is Broad-Based

Rolls-Royce grew its revenues by 14% to £20 billion, with gross profits climbing 26% to £5.1 billion as margins expanded 2.4 points to 25.6%. Operating profit climbed 38% to £3.5 billion, indicating a strong margin expansion of 3.2 points to 17.3%. Free cash flow climbed 35% to £3.3 billion.

Civil Aerospace sales grew 15% to £10.4 billion, with aftermarket sales increasing 21% and original equipment manufacturer sales growing 3%. We note that engine deliveries to OEMs were substantially lower, but a positive revenue mix leaning towards higher value large engines still led to a modest growth in revenues. IAE V2500 sales were down, driven by timing of services demand. This may seem counterintuitive given the demand for engine services as new airplanes are being delivered late. However, per platform, there can be volatility driven by cycle timing and operator decisions on maintenance scheduling and engine and airplane fleet decisions.

Regional revenues were up 3%, while business aviation sales were flat, which I believe largely reflects the high demand for business jets being constrained by the supply chain. Large engine sales grew 21%.

Gross profit increased 34% to £+2.7 billion, with margins growing 3.7 points to 25.8% on high aftermarket sales growth, including high spare engine sales, which are more profitable compared to engine deliveries to OEMs. Operating profit climbed 41% to £2.1 billion, with margins climbing 3.9 points to 20.5%. The overall story for Civil Aerospace is that of high growth in sales for the highly profitable aftermarket streams.

Revenues grew 8% to £4.8 billion for Defense with gross profits increasing 4% to £933 million with margins shrinking 80 basis points to 19.6% and operating profit increasing 9% to £689 million with margins that were more or less stable at 14.4%. OEM sales grew 18%, while services sales grew 1%, so it is the opposite of what we see in the civil aerospace segment. In the year prior, Rolls-Royce had a tailwind from a one-off £220 million sale-and-leaseback transaction. Absent of this, the revenue growth would have been 14%, which provides a better growth figure of the recurring business. Transport sales grew 20%, while naval sales grew 11%. In the high single digit growth bucket, helicopters grew 9% and combat grew 7%, while submarine sales declined 1%, driven by the one-off item. I believe that excluding this transaction, the sales growth would have been around 18% for Submarines.

So adjusted revenue growth was more or less in line with civil aerospace growth. Given that the civil aerospace sales and sales growth lean more toward profitable services growth compared to defense, the operating profit growth was less robust for defense. However, we do see that civil and defense are both growing, which also aligns with the aerospace and defense supercycle.

Power Systems sales grew 19% to £4.9 billion, while operating profit grew 60% to £852 million as margins expanded from 13.1% to 17.4%. OEM sales grew 23%, while services sales grew 12%. Interesting to note is that growth was driven by data center growth as well as governmental growth. Growth in power generation and governmental sales was 30% and 14%, while marine sales grew 7% and industrial sales declined 14%, which I believe is due to global industrial weakness. Another highlight was that the battery energy storage system, which accounts for just 2% of sales, grew 194% and is now break-even, which provides an indication that growth beyond this point will add to profits.

Rolls-Royce Guidance Lacks Detail But Points At Another Stellar Year

Rolls-Royce has provided growth estimates for 2026. Interestingly, there is no guidance for revenues or margins. Operating profit is expected to be between £4 billion and £4.2 billion, marking 14.2%-20% growth, while free cash flow has been guided to be between £3.6 billion and £3.8 billion, indicating 9%-15% growth. For Civil Aerospace a bit more color has been provided with higher OEM deliveries expected and growth in profitable shop visits with further growth in engine flight hours.

Upgrade To Mid-Term Targets Is Impressive

Rolls-Royce has been lifting its mid-term targets as execution showed that the company is delivering ahead of its initial time-bound targets. The company now expects £4.9-£5.2 billion in operating profit compared to £3.6-£3.9 expected earlier. Margin guidance has been lifted from 15%-17% to 18%-20%. With free cash flow guidance lifted by £800 million to £5-£5.3 billion.

Growth is driven by wide-body aftermarket performance and Trent XWB engine deliveries reaching break-even or slightly positive. Higher spare engine sales should positively improve both the sales and margins, while business aviation sales should improve as supply chain challenges fade.

In Defense, the increase in global demand for defense systems should drive OEM and aftermarket sales, while power systems should benefit from emerging growth in data center power demand, battery storage, and nuclear power.

So, Rolls-Royce is positioned well to capitalize on growth in aerospace and defense and energy (nuclear and battery storage), including AI-driven growth.

Rolls-Royce Stock Remains Attractive

To determine multi-year price targets, The Aerospace Forum has developed a stock screener that uses a combination of analyst consensus on EBITDA, cash flows, and the most recent balance sheet data. Each quarter, we revisit those assumptions and the stock price targets accordingly. In a separate blog, I have detailed our analysis methodology.

Rolls-Royce’s financial performance is formidable. However, somewhat counterintuitively, we are lowering the price target for 2027 from around $20 to $17.89. That is my base case price target, indicating 8% upside and 19% upside when factoring in the earnings expectations for 2028. The reason why price targets have been lowered is because the peer group trading multiple has dropped from 23.5x to 22.8x. The growth expectations remain robust with 8% growth annually for sales, EBITDA and free cash flow. The company’s median EV/EBITDA is substantially lower, but we note that the company has executed a remarkable turnaround, which I believe means that the EV/EBITDA for the prior years no longer reflects the company’s potential.

Normally, I am looking for around a 10% return per year. Rolls-Royce does not have that, but I do believe that its strong balance sheet combined with end market growth in aerospace and defense as well as power drives substantial prospects for modest upside in the stock price and increasing shareholder returns.

The image above better captures why I remain bullish on the stock. We note that sales and EBITDA continue to grow. Typically, you would also be looking for higher EBITDA margins. However, OEM sales, which tend to be lower margin (if there is any margin to start with), will also grow. So the margin profile will not necessarily show strong expansion. Those lower-margin sales, however, do pave the way for longer-term aftermarket high-margin returns. Watch items remain the ramp-up of the Airbus A350 production, which is powered by Trent XWB engines; the ramp-up for the A330neo, for which Rolls-Royce also is the exclusive provider of engines; and ramp-up and sales campaigns for the Boeing 787 on which Rolls-Royce is one of two engine suppliers. Additional long-term growth opportunities are demand from the energy market and entry into the narrow-body market.

Free cash flow is expected to grow substantially, and as the company has successfully completed its turnaround, it can substantially bring down its cash pile, returning between £7 billion and £9 billion to shareholders through repurchases. Even while doing so, the company will be able to reduce debt to near zero by 2028 and still return its free cash flow to shareholders beyond 2028 while remaining in a net-cash position.

That is why I remain bullish on the company. The upside may not be what we are looking for, but there is a potential to substantially increase dividends as the company brings down the share count.

If there is one element that I am perhaps not too fond of, then it would be that I would have rather seen Rolls-Royce bring down the share count before reinstating its dividend. That would have allowed the company to initiate a higher dividend payment per share.

Conclusion: Rolls-Royce Is Becoming More And More Attractive For The Long-Term

For Rolls-Royce, we note that the upside is not necessarily an extremely attractive one. However, what we see is that the company has laid the foundation for stronger performance in the past years, and it is now ready to return excess cash to shareholders through share repurchases and dividends. Given the formidable balance sheet, it allows the company to return all of its free cash flow to shareholders, and that creates an attractive long-term opportunity for investors.

Editor's Note: This article discusses one or more securities that do not trade on a major U.S. exchange. Please be aware of the risks associated with these stocks.

data.title: Lockheed Martin: Operationally Strong, Valuation Fully Priced - A Textbook Hold For 2026
data.description:
Lockheed Martin (LMT) enters 2026 in a position of operational strength. The backlog is strong, revenue growth is stable and free cash flow generation also looks good. Missile demand appears robust and production capacity is expanding. Management is stepping up investments in both munition and R&D.

Despite the strength of the business, the current valuation does not seem compelling for fresh investments. Even yield-focused Buys now will have to deal with ~2% dividends (~2.5-3% usually) because the share prices have appreciated recently. Lockheed Martin is almost a perfect example of a very strong Hold, with the positives and valuations in sync, leaving little asymmetry for fresh positions to capitalize on.

A one year rolling return chart does not show any abnormal breakout compared to history (so no valuation concern for existing holders), although at ~55% 1 year return, this is close to the highest levels usually seen historically. Generally these peaks have not necessarily meant corrections ensue, but definitely such peaks are usually followed by a digestion phase where rolling 1 year returns trend down.

The current stage is best reflected in the price return chart of the past 5 years below, which shows one of the sharpest and quickest rallies seen in recent history over just the past couple of months. This could also be partly attributed to a growth cooling phase, with software pressures and AI trades consolidating. Rotation could still continue and keep next year returns still positive, but the fundamentals-valuation balance indicates that this may not be the best time to enter Lockheed Martin afresh.

Demand Durable, Not Transformational

Q4 numbers show that demand is robust and revenue growth is not only strong but very visible ahead due to a solid backlog. The revenue grew by ~9% YoY reflecting a production ramp in missiles and munitions, and higher delivery volumes. The backlog reported was ~$194b - more than double the TTM revenue of ~$75b. The backlog growth was only 6%, lower than revenue growth, but it is still sufficiently strong enough for more than a few quarters of slower backlog growth before it becomes an area of discussion. Importantly, the book-to-bill ratio at 1.2 confirms demand exceeds delivery. That creates a stable operating base.

However, growth appears concentrated. Missiles & Fire Control (MFC) is expected to grow at double digits driven by PAC-3 and THAAD multiyear frameworks. Space is not growing at the same pace though (mid single digits), and outlook for Aeronautics and RMS is even more modest. Since revenue acceleration is not broad-based, the net growth expected in 2026 is ~5%, as per management guidance. That is not a negative for LMT's thesis - it actually shows topline growth coupled with strong demand and increasing production capacity for a third consecutive strong year ahead - but a broader growth story would have been a catalyst markets would have rewarded after most good news is digested. The current thesis points toward stability rather than any new inflection.

The MFC growth story also comes with a few nuances. As production ramps, the margins could be hit by 20-30bps in the initial years. Execution risks are still applicable. Make-whole clauses reduce financial risk, but they do not eliminate program timing risk. The overall picture is that of a capital intensive phase ahead with margin impacts and execution risks - so the growth excitement is tempered.

Cash Engine and Investments

The quarterly EBIT margins chart below (calculated using financials reported in Seeking Alpha) show a cluster around 11-13% (excepting two potentially charge distorted quarters). The most recent quarter actually shows a slightly lower margin. However, the important story is not a single quarter dip, but a stable band generally seen prior - there is no structural expansion seen. This looks like a pattern where revenue grows but no operating leverage breakout is evident. This is again not a negative per se, but premium multiples (we will discuss in the subsequent section) should be backed by either a breakout growth catalyst or an expanding margins profile - neither of which look supported.

The same lack of catalyst is seen in the FCF charts too. FCF has oscillated between a strict band of $5-$7.5b over the past several years. This show that growth is still being absorbed by investments. That is the profile of a stable compounder and paying mid single digit cash yield valuations for a stable compounder is not unreasonable, but not asymmetric as well.

The FCF is expected to remain strong but within a similar band in 2026 too, and management has confirmed a guidance that projects a number between $6.5b and $6.8b. FCF will remain under increased capex drag in 2026, with indicated investments of $2.5-2.8b for the year. This is actually a step up from the total capex of ~$1.65b in 2025, by almost 60% when revenue is growing at 5%. As a percentage of revenue the capex of ~2.2% of revenue today is expected to be higher at ~3.2% of an increased revenue of ~80b (more than implied by the 5% guidance). That means there is no breakout story in either margins or FCF in 2026. Again, a compounding story where valuations and recent returns become important.

Valuation Needs Inflection

At ~22x trailing free cash flow, Lockheed Martin trades above its long term mid-cycle band of ~14-18x. This is fair value in my opinion given higher valuations we have seen in the 2025 growth markets. But any rerating from here should be backed by structural margin expansion or a sustained FCF above $8b, both of which are unlikely in a capital intensive phase in 2026. Segment margins are guided at around 10.9%. Missile ramp is initially dilutive. Aeronautics margins are pressured by sustainment mix and RMS is still normalizing. Despite strong demand, there is no indication of a clear multi-year acceleration beyond the ~5% revenue growth levels we are seeing now.

Since I cannot bank upon an inflection-driven rerating ahead, the heavy lifting has to be done by compounding. That is possible. The current strength in margins and FCF can definitely support a mid single digit total return ahead. As revenue grows as guided, margins hold and capex investments translate to volume increments (without material margin erosion), the stock can compound through earnings growth and dividends. But there is no asymmetry to call for fresh cash deployment at this stage.

In fact there are risks in missile ramp and its effect on margin dilution. At ~4.6% FCF yield, valuation risks are also real. If the defense sentiment cools or overall growth narratives soften in 2026, there is room for valuations to contract (~14-18x average mid cycle levels), despite recent compression from around 25-30x levels. These are not material risks at the moment, but so is the case with the upside thesis too - nothing material enough to drive a high conviction Buy. Overall, Lockheed Martin becomes a very strong Hold position therefore, not a Buy.

data.title: Why You May Have To Rethink Your Retirement Strategy (I Sure Did)
data.description:
Introduction

Show me a 70 year old couple (with a 25 year or more time horizon) that is only 38% in equities, and I'll show you a couple getting ravaged by inflation and working at Walmart by their mid 80's. - Anonymous comment on The Wall Street Journal

I have to say this is a very unusual way to start an article. However, when I came across this comment, I thought it would be perfect to get your attention for a topic that applies to every single person reading this, regardless of whether you’re a 24-year-old college graduate or a 70-year-old who retired a few years ago.

That comment was posted under a recent Wall Street Journal article about a new retirement formula, which obviously got my attention, as retirement investing has become a much bigger part of my coverage here on Seeking Alpha in recent years.

The article was about finding a new way to assess how much risk someone can afford to take. It was basically written to improve some of the ideas that have been out there for ages, including the traditional 60/40 idea and the rule where we subtract our age from 100 to find out how much equity exposure we should take.

In my case, that number would be 70% equities, as I’m 30. For my parents, who turn 58 this year, that number would be just 42%. The 70-year-old I just used in my example would have just 30% exposure, which brings me back to the comment at the top of my article. Assuming the 70-year-old is a male, there’s a statistical chance of more than 40% he makes it to age 90, according to the JPMorgan data in the chart below.

You may know where I’m going with this. For starters, the comment on top isn’t just funny but also true, at least to a certain extent. It is still very easy to end up with money problems if you become too conservative at 70. If you’re blessed with a long life, which is obviously a good thing, you may have to cover at least two more decades of spending.

Today, I will discuss these situations and why we seriously need to rethink retirement investing.

So, before this intro gets out of hand, let’s get to it!

It’s Time To Rethink Retirement

In general, whenever we discuss retirement strategies, the problem is that every situation is unique. So many times when I cover higher-yielding stocks, some people bring up the fact that if we start investing in growth stocks early enough, we may not even need high-yield stocks.

I know that, but imagine if I wrote articles telling people who are required to buy higher-yielding stocks because of limited funds to just go back 30 years and make smarter life choices? I would become the most hated financial writer.

Even the example of the 70-year-old I just used is flawed. After all, if he were to retire with $200,000 in his investment account, which would pay him $20,000 in pre-tax income at a 10% yield, or retire with $2 million in the bank is a huge difference. With $2 million, you can reasonably expect to get $80,000 in income from a conservative 4% income portfolio.

If you also decide to sell some principal, you’re all set, especially if we include Social Security payments.

So, there’s obviously more to it than one’s age.

This brings me back to the Wall Street Journal article. The article was based on a 47-page (including the appendix) research paper that covered just how unrealistic many formulas for retirement investing are:

Research on normative household financial choices almost always gives quantitative guidance in one of two forms: a simple formula for an unrealistic setting, or numerical solutions for only a few parameter sets in a realistic setting. We propose a middle-ground approach we call practical finance: analytic approximations to optimal solutions as a function of relevant parameters in realistic settings that are easily computed in a spreadsheet. We provide such an approximation for lifecycle portfolio choice with labor income. Across 5,103 parameter sets, our approximation results in welfare that is on average only 0.06% lower than that of the optimal solution.- Choi et al. 2025

Essentially, the research is about a formula that also looks into one’s income, savings, and risk tolerance. Especially the risk tolerance is key, as I am someone who takes much bigger risks than average without losing sleep. Meanwhile, I know people who couldn’t handle investing in simple index funds. Everyone is different, as obvious as that may sound.

One big factor is that we may have to spend more time on “safe assets.” According to the report, we don’t put enough weight on personal income (paychecks) and future retirement income. Essentially, this is bond-like income that doesn’t fluctuate with the stock market.

Obviously, there are situations where that isn’t the case, like in my situation (working in finance), but, in general, that’s bond-like income. Essentially, future earnings and Social Security are a floating-rate bond that needs to be incorporated in investment decisions.

Think about it, if you have that kind of income/safety, why would you add another layer of safety in your investment portfolio?

For example, a 25-year-old with a $70 thousand annual income should, according to Choi’s formula, be 100% in stocks. That’s above traditional formulas, including the ones we just discussed:

Moreover, it’s important to keep your existing net worth into account. For example, a middle-aged couple aged 50 with a combined income of $160 thousand would have a 53% “recommended” equity position if they had $800 thousand in investable net worth compared to $400 thousand.

Here’s why that is:

But it recommends a much lower allocation, 53%, when the couple has twice as much money to invest, because in that scenario upping the equity allocation would alter the risk profile of a larger proportion of their projected lifetime resources.

“It’s more conservative when you have more money saved up,” Choi said. - WSJ

I also love the inclusion of risk tolerance (see below). Some investors can take more risks than others, as I already briefly mentioned. That’s why the model makes the case that a 70-year-old with a high-risk tolerance can easily have 64% in equities, based on an annual income of $72 thousand and a $1 million net worth. I absolutely agree with that.

With that said, I also played around with the spreadsheet that was provided by the researchers (it’s mentioned in the WSJ article. I won’t give you a direct link, as it refers to Google Sheets).

I found that a lot depends on risk aversion and one’s expected stock market return. The base numbers seem to use a real (after-inflation) return of 5.0% per year. When adjusting that number to 7.0%, even most risk-averse portfolios for higher-aged people are geared toward overweight equity positions.

Again, I think that is a much better way to look at it, as it makes much better use of one’s financial capabilities, expectations, and bond-like income for cash flows.

Although one can (and maybe should) make the case that AI increases labor uncertainty, this model seems the best approach to me, as people with a high-risk tolerance are simply leaving dollars on the table if they become conservative too fast, especially if they enjoy the safety of a high (future) income.

I think because time is our best asset (it’s finite, even for billionaires), we should focus way more on that instead of on basic allocation formulas and the obvious fact that bonds are less volatile than stocks. Less volatile doesn’t mean less risky if we look into potential lost opportunities on a long-term basis.

Now What?

In this part, I’m generalizing a lot. That may be obvious, but I still want to emphasize that none of this is personal financial advice. As I said, every situation is unique.

I believe in equities. That’s because I dislike bonds, as I simply prefer to buy ownership in actual companies that I trust. Moreover, while I own a few non-dividend-paying stocks, my goal is always to invest in companies that will, over time, provide steadily-growing dividends. Historically speaking, that’s where we buy alpha with a highly favorable volatility/risk profile, as the data below shows.

So, for the 25-year-old age group, I think 100% equities makes sense. Here, I would focus on 0.00% to 2.0% yield with a double-digit growth profile. For example, Visa (V), Broadcom (AVGO), Old Dominion Freight Line (ODFL), Carlisle Companies (CSL), Amazon (AMZN), and Alphabet (GOOGL). All of these are companies with competitive moats, low AI disruption risks (although Alphabet could fall behind if its AI models lack innovation), and secular growth tailwinds.

Generally speaking, these companies focus more on reinvesting capital than on distributing it to shareholders. When combined with attractive risk/rewards and stellar capital allocation track records, these are the companies you cannot own enough of if you’re still four decades or so away from retirement.

Also note that I am not talking about ultra-high growth stocks here, like the ones that people were buying in 2021. I believe these speculative stocks have no place in serious portfolios unless we keep the exposure to less than 10%. After all, the future flows of salary are a reason to take risks, but not an excuse to change the risk/reward of the entire portfolio.

I often use the ARK Innovation ETF (ARKK) as a proxy for these stocks:

This may sound obvious, but you would be surprised how many portfolios I encounter among young people that are filled with growth stocks that all depend on very specific developments to make their valuations work.

Ideally, if you do this for 25 to 30 years, you don’t have to make any changes. Assuming you’re really good at picking stocks, you now own companies with such high yields on cost that you can retire based on these alone.

However, for many, changing situations require changed portfolios.

If you’re over 50, depending on an average income, the equity exposure recommendation drops to 76% (based on $400 thousand net worth) and 53% ($800 thousand net worth). These are the examples I just used based on Choi’s formula.

For this situation, more mature dividend growers are perfect. Here, I would aim for yields of 2.5% to 4.0% with companies that have wide moats and a mix of cyclical and anti-cyclical growth.

Think about The Williams Companies (WMB), PepsiCo (PEP), Union Pacific (UNP), Johnson & Johnson (JNJ), Lockheed Martin (LMT), and Exxon Mobil (XOM). Essentially, these are many of the holdings of the Schwab US Dividend Equity ETF (SCHD).

In other words, to use ETFs as a proxy, we have seen this transition:

  • 20/25 years old until 50—Capital Group Dividend Value ETF (CGDV)
  • 50 until 70 (retirement)—Schwab US Dividend Equity ETF.

For my parents, I am running a strategy combining these two, as they own SCHD-like stocks that dominate their portfolio and some CGDV-like growth stocks to improve alpha and incorporate their age and income safety profile. The older they get, the more we will shift to income and safety, although we are unlikely to go into high bond positions due to the pensions they will receive. Using Choi’s logic, it would be a waste of capital to become too defensive if we don’t have to.

Now, the next stage is retirement. Again, ideally, if you’re 70 and have invested for 50 years, even moderate successes may have led to a high net worth. For example, investing $500 per month for 45 years at 7% (I went with 10% nominal and 3% inflation) turns into $1.7 million without any initial investment.

If you have a net worth that high, you can massively reduce risk. If you don’t have a high net worth (like the majority of your peers), you may have to focus on generating higher income. In that case, I would prioritize REITs and midstream stocks, which, in general, are two of my favorite places to buy income.

Here, boring is good. Think about 5% to 8% income from stocks like NNN REIT (NNN), Realty Income (O), ONEOK (OKE), Enbridge (ENB), and Energy Transfer (ET). The last one here is an MLP that issues a K-1 form.

All of these are companies with >70% payout ratios where the focus is on income. And while none of them have stock prices that are immune to recessions and other sell-offs, they all have highly predictable revenue and income.

A Few Notes On My Own Situation

Now, my personal situation is complex, and I’m, once again, breaking most rules.

  • I have 100% of my liquid net worth in equities.
  • I have no debt.
  • Although I will pay rent until September, I will have a paid-off primary residence by then, which I expect to accelerate in value at no less than 10% per year.
  • I’m 30 (as I already mentioned)
  • I’m not a millionaire yet (very close, though), but I have a high net worth for my age group, which is key for the formula.
  • I have no major safety nets (i.e., unemployment and retirement support from the government)

My income is very risky, as I have multiple projects/businesses going on, none of which result in highly predictable cash flows. Generally speaking, the research we discussed makes the case that I should own a lot of defensive stocks. However, I mostly own aggressive dividend (growth) stocks.

This is a risk I am taking because I want to use the current market environment to my advantage and because I believe the timing for cyclical value stocks is right. However, I always have a higher-income plan in mind, as I often discuss here on Seeking Alpha.

If needed, I can rapidly transition to income to protect my expenses.

The biggest risk I am taking is getting into a spot where the stock market craters, erasing a big part of my net worth, which will make it much harder to generate a decent income.

I am essentially betting on my risk profile and ability to turn above-average returns into a strong nest egg as soon as possible. I’m essentially trying to do the whole FIRE movement as a speedrun. I’ll obviously keep readers up to date on this.

For now, this is the takeaway:

Takeaway

Retirement planning is a highly challenging thing, as every situation is unique.

Today, we discussed some new findings that shed some light on important factors that tend to have a huge impact on equity exposure. This includes our expected income, risk aversion, and expected returns. Without these factors, I think traditional methods are useless.

Although I am breaking most of these rules, given that I run more risks than I should, I am essentially banking on my expected returns and risk awareness. That doesn’t work for everyone, which is why we discussed suitable investments for various age brackets.

I think by following some of these basic rules, we can do two things:

  • Create more suitable portfolios.
  • Raise more awareness about the factors we need to keep in mind when building wealth.

Needless to say, I’ll shed way more light on this in the weeks, months, and years ahead.

data.title: Nomura Small Cap Value Fund Q4 2025 Commentary
data.description:
Market review

US equities finished higher for 4Q25 amid the longest government shutdown in history. The Fund's benchmark, the Russell 2000® Value Index, advanced 3.26%. Small-cap growth equities lagged small-cap value equities during the quarter as the Russell 2000® Growth Index gained 1.22%. The large-cap S&P 500® Index advanced 2.66%, trailing small-cap value equities for the second consecutive quarter.

Sector performance within the Russell 2000 Value Index was mixed in the period as 6 of 11 sectors advanced. Within the benchmark, lower-quality stocks, those companies with a lower return on equity ('ROE'), gained more than those with higher ROEs and companies without earnings outperformed companies with earnings. The healthcare, materials, transportation, energy, and financial services sectors in the benchmark outperformed. The technology, consumer staples, and industrials sectors declined during the quarter.

The Federal Open Market Committee ('FOMC') cut rates by 25 basis points (a basis point is one hundredth of a percentage point) at both its November and December meetings, with the market expecting further cuts in 2026. The government shutdown, which spanned from October 1 to November 12, disrupted federal government data releases. The US unemployment rate, at 4.4% in December, showed little change over the quarter. Inflation continued to decline though it remained above 2% in November. Consumers' year-ahead inflation expectations have also decreased (Source: University of Michigan).

Within the Fund

For 4Q25, Nomura Small Cap Value Fund Institutional class shares slightly lagged the return of its benchmark, the Russell 2000 Value Index. Stock selection and an underweight allocation to the healthcare sector were the most notable detractors from the Fund's performance for the quarter. The Fund does not hold companies in the biotechnology or pharmaceuticals industries as they don't meet our investment discipline. However, those industries were among the strongest in the benchmark during the quarter and have a combined weight of more than 6%. Stock selection also detracted in the materials and consumer discretionary sectors. On a relative basis, stock selection contributed in the financial services, industrials, and real estate investment trusts (REITs) sectors for the quarter.

The Fund's position in medical device company Integer (ITGR) Holdings Corp. detracted for the quarter. Integer announced a reduction in customer orders in three large product lines. As a result, management stated its revenue growth and earnings for 2026 will come in below prior expectations. While we trimmed the Fund's position in Integer following the announcement, it remains in the portfolio as we believe there is long-term value in the company's shares once it can regain its previous growth trajectory. Additionally, in December, an activist investor built a position in Integer and sent a private letter to the board urging the company to refresh its board or explore a sale.

Leonardo DRS Inc. is a defense products and technology provider to military, aerospace, and intelligence customers. Shares of Leonardo DRS declined during the quarter on concerns of availability for rare earth minerals and internal investments that are constraining margins. We maintained the Fund's position in Leonardo DRS as we believe the stock's decline following its fiscal third quarter earnings report was an overreaction to short-term challenges and that the company is well aligned with military and intelligence priorities.

Kinetik Holdings Inc. Class A (KNTK) is a midstream energy company operating in the Permian Basin that provides natural gas gathering and processing services to oil and gas producers. During the quarter, shares of Kinetik declined after management reduced earnings guidance for the full year. The reduction in guidance was due to the extremely low price of natural gas in the Permian Basin, leading some customers to shut-in production rather than sell gas at a loss. While Kinetik does not take commodity risk directly, it is exposed to the volumes of its customers. We maintained the Fund's position in Kinetik since we believe there is long-term value in the company as the Permian Basin is expected to have higher gas prices by the end of 2026 due to new pipelines currently under development. Additionally, Kinetik is still a leading gas processor in the Permian Basin, the only shale basin currently experiencing significant production growth.

Herc Holdings Inc. is a general construction and specialty equipment rental company. Shares of Herc outperformed during the quarter when the company reported earnings that were better than analysts' expectations. Earlier this year, Herc acquired peer equipment rental company H&E Equipment Services (HEES). On its earnings call, Herc provided an update on the operating environment and integration milestones which made investors more comfortable with the acquisition's cost synergies and the outlook for the construction market in 2026. We added to the Fund's position in Herc during the quarter on improving fundamentals and what we viewed as the company's attractive valuation.

Bread Financial Holdings Inc. is a credit card issuer specializing in retail private-label store cards and co-branded credit cards. Bread Financial outperformed in 4Q as credit metrics proved more resilient than anticipated. Lower-than-expected delinquency and net charge-off rates demonstrated the success of its operational excellence initiatives. In the quarter, Bread Financial increased its dividend and repurchased its shares, which grew the company's tangible book value per common share. We maintained the Fund's position in Bread Financial. (BFH)

TTM Technologies Inc. manufactures advanced printed circuit boards ('PCB') and radio frequency ('RF') components and assemblies. Shares of TTM Technologies outperformed when demand for the company's advanced PCBs remained strong as evidenced by better-than-expected sales in the company's aerospace and defense and data center computing segments. TTM Technologies' products are in high demand for use in artificial intelligence ('AI') computing and advanced defense-related radar systems. We maintained the Fund's position in TTM Technologies as we believe the company's prospects remain positive.

Outlook

In our view, small cap valuations remain attractive relative to large cap valuations and the Russell 2000 Value Index's relative P/E (price to earnings) to the Russell 2000 Growth Index remains below the long-term historical average. At the time of our commentary, 2026 earnings growth estimates for the Fund's holdings are expected to be over 10%, which is in line with the EPS (earnings per share) growth expectations for large-cap companies.

The Fund ended 4Q with overweight allocations to sectors where we viewed valuations and free cash flow generation as more attractive. At the end of 4Q, the Fund maintained relative sector overweights compared to the index in the industrials and financial services sectors. During the quarter, we purchased a consumer finance company with proceeds from the sale of a regional bank that was fully valued. The transactions maintained the Fund's financial services sector overweight.

The Fund remains underweight the healthcare, consumer discretionary, energy, and materials sectors. In the materials sector, we purchased two new positions and sold two. We purchased shares of Axalta Coating Systems Ltd (AXTA), in October, and sold the Fund's position in diversified chemicals company, Huntsman Corporation (HUN). One month later, Akzo Nobel NV (AKZOY) entered into a definitive agreement to acquire Axalta via a merger of equals. Ryerson Holding Corporation (RYI), a leading value-added processor and distributor of industrial metals, and Olympic Steel Inc. (ZEUS), a leading US metals service center, announced in October that they entered into a definitive agreement to merge in an all-stock transaction. We owned Ryerson in the portfolio and following the merger announcement, we exited Ryerson and purchased Olympic Steel.

There were two additional Fund holdings that announced merger agreements in 4Q which remained holdings as of period-end. Plymouth Industrial REIT Inc. (PLYM), which owns warehouses and industrials properties across the Midwest and East Coast, agreed to be acquired by a Private Equity group for cash. Cadence Bank (CADE) is headquartered in Mississippi and has operations in several higher-growth Sunbelt markets. Cadence agreed to be acquired by Huntington Bancshares Inc (HBAN) in an all-stock transaction.

Our team's disciplined investment philosophy remains unchanged. We continue to focus on bottom-up (stock-by-stock) security selection with a focus on quality companies that, in our view, trade at attractive valuations, generate strong free cash flow, and return cash to shareholders through share buybacks, dividends, and/or debt reduction.

References

data.title: Helix Energy Solutions Reports Net Income And Free Cash Flow For Q4 2025
data.description:
Helix Energy Solutions (HLX) reported in-line Q4 2025 financial results last Tuesday. Revenue was down overall due to seasonality and lower utilization, but the company reported net income and free cash flow. Helix shared a positive 2026 outlook with a few multi-year contracts, although Q1 2026 will be weak again due to seasonality. The company is currently undervalued and has a strong balance sheet. The stock price has gained 7% over the last year. It is up 4.4% since I covered the company last March on Seeking Alpha. The energy sector has seen some upticks recently with investors rotating out of tech stocks. I continue my rating of a hold.

Operations

Helix specializes in deep-water well enhancement and decommissioning. Its services include robotics for underwater trenching, seabed clearance, and offshore construction. Helix also works in shallow water abandonment, including offshore oilfield decommissioning and reclamation. The company has operations in Europe (North Sea), West Africa, Asia (Thailand and Australia), South America (Brazil), the U.S. Gulf, and the U.S. East Coast. Its operating segments include Well Intervention, Robotics, Shallow Water Abandonment, and Production Facilities.

Q4 2025 Results

Helix reported Q4 2025 revenue of $334.2 million, representing a decrease of 5.8% YoY and a decrease of 11.3% QoQ. Gross profit was $50.6 million, a decrease of 14% YoY and a decrease of 23.3% QoQ. Gross margins were 15.15% versus 16.57% YoY and 17.51% QoQ.

Net income was $8.3 million versus $20.1 million YoY and $22.1 million QoQ. The company reported free cash flow of $107 million. Cash and ST investments increased to $445.2 million. Helix reported $315 million in funded debt and a negative net debt of $137 million.

Market consensus for Q1 2026 revenue is $260.89 million, a decrease YoY and QoQ. The company reports in April.

Segment Performance and Outlook

The chart below breaks down revenues and utilization by segment.

Although Q4 is seasonally weak, the company reported strong performance in its Robotics segment and Shallow Water Abandonment segment. Shallow Water Abandonment was down YoY due to a slowdown in operations in the Gulf of America. Well Intervention was weaker YoY and QoQ because of lower utilization of the Sea Helix 1 and the Well Enhancer. Sea Helix 1 was transitioning between long-term contracts. The Sea Enhancer was lower due to seasonal shutdown in the North Sea. During Q4, the Seawell was stacked, which also led to lower utilization overall. Robotics was down YoY due to winter seasonality. Utilization was mostly down YoY and QoQ. Production faculties decreased due to the Thunder Hawk field being shut down and due to lower oil prices from the Droshky field.

The company said that performance over 2026 may be weaker due to dry docking and maintenance. Its Sea Helix 1 will undergo a 10-year special maintenance lasting 45 days, which will negatively impact revenue. Its Thunder Hawk production facility will not be online again until Q2 2026. The company will look at mergers and acquisitions during 2026 in an attempt to offset potentially weak revenue performance.

The company reported some synergies for 2026. The Sea Helix 1, despite some downtime for its special survey, will enter a three-year contract for Petrobras, as will its Siem Helix 2. The company secured a multi-year contract in the North Sea to work on 34 subsea wells. The work has brought the Seawell back into action as of February. The company foresees better results at the end of 2026 and for 2027.
